claim: Price on perceived customer value, not costs. Cost-plus leaves money on the table.
rationale: Customers pay for benefits and problem-solving; inward-looking cost-plus ignores WTP and positioning.

claim: 3 Cs: Costs set floor, Customer value sets ceiling, Competition sets positioning.
rationale: Ignoring any C yields suboptimal, uncompetitive pricing.

claim: Penetration pricing suits price-sensitive markets with economies of scale; deters entrants.
rationale: Volume lowers unit cost and builds share; must plan to raise price or upsell later.

claim: Skimming pricing for innovative, low-competition products: start high, lower over time.
rationale: Captures early adopter surplus, recoups R&D, builds premium image before broadening.

claim: Use tiered subscriptions with clear differentiation; each tier must serve distinct segments.
rationale: Captures varied WTP across segments; clarity prevents confusion and drives upgrades.

claim: Freemium works with near-zero marginal costs and network effects; expect low conversion.
rationale: Needs massive free base; viable only when serving free users is cheap and network effects raise value.

claim: Dynamic pricing maximizes revenue on perishable inventory; adjust by demand/supply/time/competition.
rationale: Unsold perishable capacity is lost; dynamic adjustments capture value peaks and stimulate lows.

claim: Pure cost-plus ignores value and competition; caps profit or loses sales.
rationale: Creates no efficiency incentive and misaligns with WTP.

claim: Price wars destroy value for all—eroded margins, commoditization, stalled innovation.
rationale: Train customers to expect discounts; recoverability is low.

claim: Not researching WTP leads to under/overpricing; feature focus hides value perception.
rationale: Guesses misprice; features users won't pay for get built; sales lost or profit forfeited.

claim: Ignoring competitive response makes pricing obsolete; reactions can trigger wars or share loss.
rationale: Pricing is ecosystem-based; must monitor rivals and shifts continuously.

claim: No clear pricing objectives = arbitrary, reactive decisions and misalignment.
rationale: Ambiguity blocks measurement, learning, and coordinated action.

claim: Calculate Economic Value to Customer (EVC) vs. next best alternative; price as a share of that value.
rationale: EVC translates benefits into financial terms; ideal for B2B with clear ROI.

claim: Use price elasticity analysis: elastic → lower price raises revenue; inelastic → higher price raises revenue.
rationale: Elasticity guides direction; substitutes and necessity drive elasticity. Testing reveals reality.

claim: A/B test pricing on small segments; test one variable; require statistical significance.
rationale: Real behavior beats guesses; small tests de-risk costly mistakes; enables continuous tuning.

claim: Use anchoring: show higher-priced options first to set reference points.
rationale: Anchoring bias makes target options seem reasonable; useful in tiered/pricing comparisons.

claim: Use decoy effect: add a less attractive option to steer preference to target.
rationale: Relative comparison highlights target’s superiority; common in tiering/packaging.

claim: Bundle to raise AOV and move slow SKUs; bundling obscures component prices vs competitors.
rationale: Perceived value of bundles exceeds parts; simplifies decisions and resists direct price shopping.

claim: Prestige pricing: high prices signal exclusivity/quality; avoid discounting.
rationale: For status goods, high price is part of value; discounting erodes exclusivity.

claim: Subscriptions create predictable recurring revenue and higher LTV; annual with discount reduces churn.
rationale: Ongoing relationships improve planning and retention; annual commitments stabilize revenue.

claim: Choose a value metric that scales with customer value/usage (per-user, per-transaction, usage-based).
rationale: Alignment makes pricing feel fair, lowers entry barrier, and captures growth upside.

claim: Amazon adjusts prices millions of times daily using dynamic pricing to maximize revenue.
rationale: Real-time algorithms optimize competitive positioning and transaction value across huge catalog.

claim: Netflix evolved to tiered streaming and raised prices tied to content investment and value growth.
rationale: Tiered plans capture different WTP; justified increases kept churn manageable.

claim: HubSpot freemium CRM drives PLG, converting to paid hubs; free tier as growth engine.
rationale: Free creates familiarity and switching costs; paid tiers capture value as needs grow.

claim: Rolex/Louis Vuitton use prestige pricing—high price as value signal; rarely discount.
rationale: Price is integral to exclusivity and status appeal; discounting harms brand equity.

claim: Uber/Lyft surge pricing balances supply/demand; transparency mitigates backlash.
rationale: Dynamic pricing for perishable driver time optimizes matches during spikes/lulls.

claim: If no one pushes back on price, you’re likely underpriced; healthy resistance indicates value capture.
rationale: Zero friction suggests price is below perceived value; optimal pricing has acceptable friction.

claim: If growth is 'up and to the right' but causes are unknown, you lack control; supplement metrics with qualitative insight.
rationale: Unexplained success is fragile; need causal understanding to sustain and respond.

claim: Pricing is continuous optimization; monitor KPIs, feedback, competitors, and adjust regularly.
rationale: Markets/costs change; static pricing drifts from value and positioning.

claim: Use Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) to justify higher upfront prices; show lifecycle savings.
rationale: Shifts focus from purchase price to long-term value—effective for durable/enterprise goods.
